title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate GarysGym’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $1,479 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$51×29=$1,479 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5CE9@

The response calculates GarysGym’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $1,479 and shows the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$51×29=$1,479 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5CE9@

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the quantity demanded will increase by less than 5% and/or does not explain that the demand is inelastic in this price range because marginal revenue is negative.
The response states that the quantity demanded will increase by less than 5% and explains that the demand is inelastic in this price range because marginal revenue is negative.

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at a quantity of 16 units GarysGym’s marginal product is decreasing and/or does not explain that the marginal cost is rising.
The response states that at a quantity of 16 units GarysGym’s marginal product is decreasing and explains that the marginal cost is rising.

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 22 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies that the firm’s profit-maximizing quantity as 22 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns positive economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is below the demand curve, or the firm charges a price above the average total cost, or P > ATC MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

The response states that the firm earns positive economic profit and explains that the firm’s average total cost curve is below the demand curve, or the firm charges a price above the average total cost, or P > ATC MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, GarysGym does not have a dominant strategy and/or does not explain that when E-Fitness chooses to advertise, GarysGym’s payoff is higher when it chooses to lower the price ( $580 > $350 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4098@ ), and when E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, GarysGym’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain the price ( $700 > $460 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4094@ ); therefore, GarysGym does not have a dominant strategy.

The response states that no, GarysGym does not have a dominant strategy and explains that when E-Fitness chooses to advertise, GarysGym’s payoff is higher when it chooses to lower the price ( $580 > $350 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4098@ ), and when E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, GarysGym’s payoff is higher when it chooses to maintain the price ( $700 > $460 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4094@ ); therefore, GarysGym does not have a dominant strategy.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the Nash equilibrium as GarysGym lowers its price and E-Fitness advertises ($580, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4137@ , and/or does not explain that if GarysGym chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $580 to $350, and if E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $500 to $200; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies the Nash equilibrium as GarysGym lowers its price and E-Fitness advertises ($580, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4137@ , and explains that if GarysGym chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $580 to $350, and if E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $500 to $200; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and/or does not explain that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for GarysGym to lower its price and E-Fitness to advertise ($580, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4137@ because if GarysGym chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $580 to $350, and if E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $500 to $300 ( $200 + $100 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4073@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explain that with the offer E-Fitness’ dominant strategy will continue to be to advertise because its payoff will always be higher ( $450 > $400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4090@ and $500 > $300 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408B@ ), and since GarysGym has no dominant strategy, it is better off to lower its price ( $580 > $350 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4098@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that no, this offer will not result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the Nash equilibrium strategies will still be for GarysGym to lower its price and E-Fitness to advertise ($580, $500) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4137@ because if GarysGym chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $580 to $350, and if E-Fitness chooses to not advertise, its payoff will decrease from $500 to $300 ( $200 + $100 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4073@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explain that with the offer E-Fitness’ dominant strategy will continue to be to advertise because its payoff will always be higher ( $450 > $400 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4090@ and $500 > $300 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@408B@ ), and since GarysGym has no dominant strategy, it is better off to lower its price ( $580 > $350 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4098@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
